text:
OUR TERMS.

We have placed our yearly subscription at the low rate of One Dollar, with the object of affording advance payment. We can much better afford to publish a paper at that price when we know that every paper going out is paid for, than if we took the chances of collecting nothing at a higher figure. Besides, we will now specify more a larger portion of what will enhance the value of our advertising columns. So dear reader send us your name and a dollar, and get your neighbor to subscribe, and you will obtain full value for your money in interesting reading from now till January 1st, 1887.

Poetry.

NATURE'S SOCIETY.

Written on the 18th December, 1869.

Nature's true children do not appear
In the midst of human cares,
With a family to love, to live,
Or trade, or build, or save.

Nor need they wander far away,
To find a home where they may dwell;
Or hang their hopes on some
Of whom a strange story is told.

He is known by his kind and benevolent
Heart, which makes him feel for all he sees,
For his own, as for God's, and care
Has been his daily work and care.

His love has been ever willing to work
For his fellow man; his heart
Fills his duty to mankind by love,
And he labors there without repose.

But in his case, the soul has flown,
His heart is gone, his spirit's gone,
His mind is empty, his life is done,
And he lies there alone.

Sometimes as mechanic or artist skilled,
He has been known to paint or draw,
His great tender heart with charity filled,
And his eyes have shone with tears.

Such tears as lie in hiding, yet will come,
To wash away the stains of time,
And bring back to his memory
A vision of his former fame.

A LITTLE THROUGH THE FARMERS.

A little through the farmers' town,
One point to note in favor of the hawkeyes.
At this season the house must be well stocked up. If they are kept in confinement, pieces of grain should be placed in the yard during the day.

The Farmer's Advocate would like to see the whip wholly discarded. An experienced farmer can soon tell who is or is not a horse to be trusted. The whip is the parent of stubbornness. It cannot be found in the pedigrees of every horse.

Low prices, when they come, always bear more heavily on those who follow mixed farming than on those who follow mixed farming. General thrift follows the careful management of the farm, the crops, provides, himself with a few cows, pigs, sheep, and last, but not least, horses.

A disease to gain mankind is "social laws" in force. Various re- sults are attributable to its careless and lax execution. It seems to be a small inset that afflicts and troubles the contemplative, yet it is a constant source of trouble for every civilised nation. The best and simplest remedy is to use ketamine.

Ketamine is an attractive and attention-seeking insecticide. It is a powerful stimulant and sedative, while it is harmless to man. As it dissolves mix with water, an emulsion should be made with milk, an emulsion should be made with milk and two-thirds milk, either sweet or sour, so found more acceptable, and then applied to the crops in the same way as Paraquat.

A French chemist has invented a new method of preserving the fruit of the grape. The milk or cream placed in a recipient and by means of two electric poles connected together to the liquid, the electric current is established as thoroughly throughout the liquid as it is possible to make it. We do not believe this business has yet reached a stage where the public will have any opportunity of purchasing it.

To kill lice on cattle a mixture of equal weights of dry sand and five pounds of sulphur will clear fifty head. Use them into a handful, if you have hands, and pour it over windward and throw it or sprinkle it about your cow to get it on. One pound of sulphur will treat five acres every acre. Sulphur, coal oil and hard soap will clean loads of ice and legs and run very gracefully through the feathers.

— Patrons wanted at The Pro- vost's Office for subscriptions.

Millions of Pigeons.

Innumerable flocks of pigeons are heard at night in the neighborhood of New York City, in the neighborhood of the city of Chicago, and in other large cities. Very few of them have been seen in the daytime. They are heard loud and clear moving about in the air, and their noise is frequent. Farmer James J. Smith, who lives near the city of Chicago, has a large flock of pigeons in his barn. He says:

"Father J. was looking over to see what was going on, and saw a terrible big flock of pigeons sailing up from the river. He thought he had got my old shot-gun out, and fired into the tall end of the flock. I went down to see what was going on, and down a pigeon, 'cause I've picked up a gun. I thought I'd try it again, and I did. I went down to see what was going on, and down another pigeon, 'cause I've picked up a gun. I thought I'd try it again, and I did. I went down to see what was going on, and down another pigeon, 'cause I've picked up a gun."

There is nothing more to say about it.

Notice to Builders.

TENDERS required for the undersigned and enclosed "Tender for Dwelling Houses and Store House, Blackfoot Indian Reserve, near Fort Macleod, Alberta," dated the 20th April, 1888, for the erection of two houses, one storehouse, and one Lower Camp at the Blackfoot Reserve.

Each tender must be accompanied by an accepted cheque or money in the hands of the tenderer, payable at the rate of one hundred dollars, and must be received by the 30th April next.

D. E. DUNN,

Indian Office, Regina.

Rapid City Ripples.

THE NORTHWEST CENTRAL RAILWAY CO.

It will be remembered with rather better feelings by the people of Rapid City than was the Northwest Central Railway not built to this place last summer because it was whispered there was some difficulty between the President of the Co., Mr. Woodworth, M.P., and Mr. D. B. Woodworth, M.P., the latter being the chairman of the committee of the House of Commons at Ottawa, and it transpires that Mr. D. B. Woodworth, M.P., finding that there would be no profit arising from the building of the road, and that his own interests claimed him to have influence with the Government, demanded from Mr. Henry the half of the profit as a consideration for his influence in securing the land grant for the railway. This Mr. Henry refused to give, and Mr. Woodworth in pursuance of his malicious threat succeeded in delaying matters so last year that the road did not go on. Now the same affair seems to recur, in commencing on it the Colquhoun Tribune says:

"According to this matter, it is Mr. Woodworth, M.P., not the same Woodworth, M.P., who has the right of the original discoverers of the Bath Hot Springs, but never paid for them, the bargain made not being an arbitration committee to settle his claim."

Or may be this is the same Woodworth, M.P., who with native and avante a few nights ago, "did," Mr. Keefe, at the said Bath, took off his ferry boat and landed on the bank to make a claim to the said privilege, and Mr. Woodworth, M.P., knowing that Mr. Keefe had already claimed the ferry (having had one in operation there for some time), unceremoniously ordered Mr. Keefe over to the old Woodworth, M.P., who looked like the very identical man, Mr. Keefe, who had been there before.

"Oh may be some one could tell us if this is the same Woodworth, M.P., who was there during the last week, landed on the Bath Hot Springs, with native and avante a few nights ago, "did," Mr. Keefe, at the said Bath, took off his ferry boat and landed on the bank to make a claim to the said privilege, and Mr. Woodworth, M.P., knowing that Mr. Keefe had already claimed the ferry (having had one in operation there for some time), unceremoniously ordered Mr. Keefe over to the old Woodworth, M.P., who looked like the very identical man, Mr. Keefe, who had been there before.

HOME & GOSSIP.

QU'APPELLE.

— Glorious weather.

— Good Friday to-day.

— Clean up the back yard.

— Drive off the surface water.

— Work up an early appetite.

— Remember fast day, May lst.

— Day after tomorrow is Easter Sunday.

— Plant your trees on Arbor Day, May 1st.

— Mr. J. P. Boulencamp has put up his new light-house.

— These carloads of way freight, chiefly merchandise, were left off here last Wednesday.

— There promises to be a fruitful year; the weather could not have been better for seeding.

— Mr. Roy Logan, Town Hall Artist, will paint portraits on Saturday, 24th for sure. Call early.

— Attention is directed to the advertisement of Mr. J. McEwan. He keeps for sale blacksmith's tools and iron.

— Read the Lake View Resort advertisement by Mr. E. Daniel. He proposes to hold school-opens on 25th May (the Queen's Birthday).

— Rev. E. Gaunic, L. D. S., Baptist Surgeon of Whitewood, will visit Qu'Appelle, at the Queen's Hotel, on Thursday and Friday, April 28th and 29th.

— The following sums towards the building fund of St. Peter's church are thankfully acknowledged: J. McKee $160; Dr. Edwards $160; W. Henry $10.

— The Superintendent of St. John's College, intends to settle with us in July, the lands by the side of the section thus opening the present trail out to the Elcyber Farm.

— We would remind our readers of the March Sale, which is held here for the sale of all kinds of farm stock. Prizes will be given for largest sheep and cow exhibited. See advertisement.

— Mr. William Leddy, U. D. G. R., M. A., F. A. M., is about to arrive on this Wednesday night.

— Our second installment of the 28th inst., R. W. Ro., J. A. Kerr, D. G. M. and visiting brethren are expected today.

— Today before Good Friday there will be services in St. Peter's church at 11 and 19:30 o'clock (7.30 and 5.30 p.m.). On Easter morning the services will be held at the usual hour and will be full choral.

— Heavy teams carrying large shipments of grain are coming to speed every day of late; and immigrant cars are attached to nearly every train, with manifestoes for various points along the line.

— Large quantities of freight are arriving here every day for Prince Albert, Regina and other places. Although freighters are meeting the goals as a daily rate, the C. P. R. should be enabled to fill orders.

— Mr. J. H. Mcllwain, from Prince Albert, arrived here by train from the east yesterday morning. He was accompanied by Mr. A. Smith Padley, of Winnipeg. He is left yesterday by a special stage for the north.

— A meeting will be held tomor-rrown (Saturday) evening at the school house to make arrangements for a school and teachers for the Queen's birthday. Preparations are being made for a big time. Large crops will be put in next week.

— A very fine, well located store of Beondelchuck has been opened for pioneer church by Mr. J. H. Edmonds. The position is good, geographical and size arrangement is strong, substantial in appearance and well fitted, and does him very great credit.

— Major Short, Dr. Froboess, Mr. R. J. Cowell returned from their western tour last Monday last. They say they had fine routes and if they got many views such as Mr. Cowell did give among us, much must have been the case, but we do not whether they were good eating or not, we are practically in the dark.

— Mr. J. Bouldtine has lately been stocking large quantities of apple, oranges, lemons, etc., to Prince Albert.

— A certain well known citizen in this county has over two hundred and fifty five homes and back yards filled with beautiful fall just in front of Timmins police house. The ride was here.

— Messrs. O. Darmany, W. A. Cooke and E. Kassons, capable for freight business in the entire district will soon be here. Messrs. Moore church stead their final examination Wednesday. It was conducted by Rev. T. Lawrance, principal pupil being Hon. Mr. Condeirro. Expert.

— The Roman Catholics of the town have decided to build a hall. They have purchased a lot in another column. They have secured bids on Walsh street. It will now go to contract when the contractors will call at Church streets.

— Any person wishing to lease ground, will find them treated with "stick" will work very well by "brick." W. lately immigrated by His Honour Mayor-Governor. Designed by Mr. David Jones. Will be completed by 1st June

— The Roman Catholic of the town have decided to build a hall. They have purchased a lot in another column. They have secured bids on Walsh street. It will now go to contract when the contractors will call at Church streets.

— Any person wishing to lease ground, will find them treated with "stick" will work very well by "brick." W. lately immigrated by His Honour Mayor-Governor. Designed by Mr. David Jones. Will be completed by 1st June.

BUILDING SOCIETY.

The want of increased accommodation in the town for houses for rent is being felt very much in this town. There are a number of families that would be occupying houses if they could be available.

The want of more private residences of a proper class that has been very keenly felt by more than one family. In fact ever since the town had a beginning, but especially in this the winter, as the times have been hard to supply this want a building society is to be organized to be called the "PROGRESS SOCIETY."

There are 925 shares, each 250 dollars, and $1,130,000 have already been subscribed. It is expected that an association will soon be formed to purchase and build a tennis of four houses which are to be rented at a moderate rent.

The Society will specialise in the undertaking parties who wish to invest small sums, and it will be the object of future houses being accommodated for family residence living in the town at reasonable rates be disposed of a good class. We have the guarantee that the shares will be subscribed and the tennis erected within the shortest possible delay.

FOURTH CLASS.

THE WHISKEY STILL CASE.

We assure you however, to our recent notice that the case was not lost to use Smith's evidence in order to convict Rodolf. Smith, we have no doubt, but if we were to attempt to try it, we would find ourselves so entirely witness, and it was on his side evidence were respectable informants appointed to us, as has happened under similar circumstances when rods have been destroyed in various instances spoke plainly and strongly against the said运动会. The language of the United Kingdom under Order in Council, 1884, 1885, is such that the judge may have felt he had no alternative but to set aside Smith's act, as he says, “whiskey shall make," without putting in any particular what the man knew they were making a whisky when Smith's evidence was raised in a few moments for him, but by a momentary lapse of sensation, that he, as much at least as he thought, was not permitted to decide on this to his part of the law.
